item.title: Syndicate Update #2:Â Decentralizing the Syndicate, Building in the Open, and Introducing Community Self-Governance
item.dc:creator: John Wooten
item.content:encoded:
Img 1600*667px fit as "Large"; vid 840*473; cover 353*330

Prerequisite Reading: Thing. [Open-Sourcing TAD3 Announcement](https://wooten.link/opensource)TLDR: relevant info.

As communicated in the [first Syndicate update](SYND_UPDATE_1), everything started for Block Transfer in our [foundational thesis](https://wooten.link/thesis). Made [with the help of a classmate](https://wooten.link/explainer) (see description), that was the start of a journey thatâs now been over four years in the marking.



When we finished the thesis, [I was excstatic](href_INSTA_PUBLISHED_THESIS_YAY!) to present anyone with a framework for a transfer agent depository, via SSRN. But I quickly learned that educational publication were quite like traditional marketing. It seemed to take either a known reputation or marketing dollars to get any attention, as Iâd learned over years writing and subsequently promoting [my book](https://wooten.link/n2n).



Since I didnât have either of those, I went back to trading for half a year after school shut down for covid. Thatâs when I was on [uberman](HREF_UBERMAN_VID), and it was a stellar time Iâll always cherish. But it was also a time when I fully felt internal pain due to the vast trading and settlement inneficiencies omnipresent in the fincnacial system. The turning point for me that got me focused again on order books came one quiet weekend at Tech.



At the start of the week, I had put a few hundred dollars on a long 1000X forex pair. By the time I was grilling out after the closing bell Friday, my position was worth upwards of $16,000. But the market started slipping the remainder of the weekend. By the time I could trade after the opening bell Monday, the position was barely worth a couple thousand bucks.



As any good trader familiar with stop-losses will tell you, this is truly an unnaceptable slide. But there was nothing I could do about it since I, like billions of others, was locked out of the market until âregular trading hours.â Meanwhile, a select few institutions, many of whom denied me a broker account, sold out massive stakes for windfall profits at the elevated prices.



## Decentralized Work



Decentralized work is permissionless work. It works because anyone, anywhere, anytime can choose of their own volition to embark down a career path simply because it intruiges them. I know from experience that the best trades often come on a whim. Theyâre a combination of preparation, subconcious pattern recognition, and a little bit of luck. None of that works when you need to pass through five rounds of interviews to write your first line of code.



When I wrote Nine to Noon, I just decided one day to start typing words in a free document editor. Every source I used was freely avaliable online without any kind of special account. And every hour I invested trading to learn the market reacted to more-or-less the same financial statistics avaliable to anyone else with a Yahoo Finance bookmark.



When we lower the bar ot participate in the economy, we open our organziations up to the innovative ideas of hidden genuises capable of so much more than command-and-control forced labor. (ONE_WORD_IDEALLY) We need those permissionless systems for the next generation of asset managers, software developers, and free thinkers. For the sake of progress itself, I posit that society ought best advance rapidly under these principles.



### Conwayâs Law



What I am proposing is a new kind of work that hasnât been deployed at scale yet. I believe deeply that the organization of workers naturally becomes apparent in final products. Might we consider the best structure for creating an equal, transparent, and efficient market for capital?



We know the existing financial instutions rely on centralized work schemes. They have their âpyramidâ with workers on the bottom and a select few executives at the top. I wholeheartedly believe this thought style led to the problematic present chain of custody:



[IMG_YELLOWPAPER_but_white_bc_IMG_OF_DTCC_Pyramid](https://wooten.link/yellow)



If we believe in an ideal future where everyone owns their own keys to their securities, many of these intermediaries cease relevance. Their purposes, while historically ustified, can get automated in the context of modern blockchains. If we agree that a market with less middlemn, gatekeepers, ad beurocrats best serves investors, regulators, and issuers; then it follows that we need a decentralized market.



^TODO_MUST_STANDARDIZE_IRI_ORDER,prob_end_most_imprtnat



A decentralized market gives the power back to users of the systme, not its maintainers. It captures value for these users in toto, not a select few middlemen scraping off [processing fees](HREF_JEFFRIES_PERCNET_FEE_TWEET). And by its distirbuted nature, this new market requires a different approach to work.



Over the past seven years uncoving the blockchain landscape, Iâve seen this new approach flourish. Iâve heard and seen thousands of developers self-organize online through thier own research to uncover a project. They pour thousands of hours into bettering these systems, sometimes without a cent of pay or even an identifying name.



If this unique collaboration structure can produce an industry worth XYZ trillion dollars, almost entirely informally—do you think thereâs much more potential hiding latent? Presently, almost the only way to develop these web3 systems is to follow Wall Streetâs lead. You learn the market, understand the code, and go through some kind of politicking to land pay at a centralized company.



There are some projects that try to âsolveâ this porblem, aiming for a more decentralized workforce. But then these projects themselves are a central group of select actors. The parallel would be us trying to fix Wall Street by opening a centralized ATS.



Indeed, while these blockchains have succeeded using token incentives alone in these formative years, uncapped growth isnât a long-term sustainable work incentive. This is why modern ealry hires in tech hubs still want good âol greenbacks. Stock options alone simply canât pay rent, buy groceries, or cover childcare.



The question for me always comes back to asset management. How do you allocate pay without a central abriter of salaries? I believe the answer lies in the crowdsourcing ethos underlying the industry.



### New Technologies



Most of what I know about programming came from the introduction to Python call at Georgia Tech. At least foundationally, this was my big moment of understanding how computers process logic. I remember learning about `for` loops in class one week and building an EDGAR scrapign bot with them the next.



APIs in particular were such a transformative concept to learn about as a massive numbers geek. I warm up inside just at the thought of basic price action data feeds. Once I understood that I could apply coding to the markets, I was off to the races to build this key tooling as fast as possible.



Early on, I remember the joy of running very basic scripts through Repl.it and seeing my results immediately. It was an addictive high until it wasnât, and that generally happened when I got dictated a lackluster homework assignment. Then it was stress and headaches until I could get back to the stock market.



As I learned more about Stellar over the years reading the docs, open-source code, and public discussions, I realized my present vision for our markets. Then, on XOZY_DATE_FIRST_PY_TAD3_COMMIT, I started [building it](commit hash githubHREF). For XYZ_18_ABC months, I kept iterating in the public light, as the codebase was open but not free.



The community gave me some stellar feedback on my ideas, and they were sincerely welcoming towards my work. But outside of periodic technical questions, it was self-paced independent work any moment I could find some spare time. It was this repo where I developed many of the infrastructural choices underlying the Syndicate by the nature of encountering them in actual build design considerations.



I believe this is a unique modern approach to building things that wasnât possible before the widespread use of public code repositories. Given the length of time it probably took Nakamoto, they couldnât build like this in the open back then. Indeed, the âdefinativeâ central whitepaper and initial deployment of Bitcoin reflect the isolated, painstaking, and siloed developmemt patterns of traditional organizations.



Part of the quadary is a fear of theft. What if someone copyed an early version of Nakamotoâs work? By keeping the draft stages private, we can ignore this risk.



Bitcoin might have succeeded, but what about the tens or even hundreds of similar concepts that died in the dark? Condemned to the lonely pages of an academic journal, an abandoned hard drive, or even an unfinished private git repo. I believe that the best scalable efficincies may have emmerged earlier if everyone had insights into these comparisons.



In high school, I had an idea for compensating writers without selling ads, which I kept top-secret. I remember reluctantly spilling out the basic concept for MonerAds on a date, only after extensive pleading. Over time, I shared the idea with my friends more and more, until the point where I was talking about it publicly and on YouTube.



Despite all this sharing, nobody copied the concept. Nobody ever asked to even look over the nonexistent code. In fact, I actually attracted collaborators that helped me flesh the concept out.



Ultimately, we uncovered an established firm building the tech. Combined with the challenges of mining efficinecies in volatile markets, that business ceased operations. But its demise was quite explicitly not the result of copycats because ideas are a dime a dozen, and it all comes down to execution.



## Open Source Wall Street



As communicated, I am the sole person working on the Syndicate. And indeed, as a corporation with one shareholder, thatâs probably how things should be. But my point is that thatâs not how markets should be.



Can you imagine a market where one company controls everything from exchange, settlement, and brokerage? Well I certainy can historically vis-a-vi the Buttonwood Agreement. (TODO_STYLIZE_VIS_A_VI) But the natural law of copetition in a free market has brought thousands of competitiors into the space since.

























But over the years, I ran into roadblocks that my extremely limited development understanding could overcome. For context, it took me at least two hours in a study group to set up command-line Truffle.

item.title: 37 Startup Secrets info
item.dc:creator: John Wooten
item.content:encoded:
Startup Pitching Best Practices ð

Secret #1: Have a Long-Term Goal

I believe it's a crime to start any business without reading Think and Grow Rich. Of relevance from the book (that theoretically birthed the personal development industry) is the importance, strategy, and framework for setting goals. Good long-term goals make for high-quality company aspirations. These visions not only help rally your team, but they also serve as the bedrock of any successful startup pitch - in my opinion. Pitching your business ultimately comes down to telling a good story through your goals.


Angel Harris:

Yes I actually have read Think and Grow Rich by Napoleon Hill. Definitely a fantastic read!
"I apply things that I've learned from that read everyday. In our business and in my personal life. That was actually one of the best reading experiences in my life."
Secret #2: Create Your Written Business Plan

(Based on the company's long-term goal) 

Create Your Written Business Plan video from SBA potentially (or make one)


Clearly articulate your business plan, including how you intend to use the funds raised. This is fundamental for investors to understand the potential and direction of the investment.



Top Questions Answered

Why is your company important?
What is your invention or innovation?
What is the problem you are trying to solve?
What have you done so far to solve the problem?
What is the expected impact when the business succeeds?
What company aspects are novel, useful, or non-obviousness - setting you apart?
Describe the market: who will buy it, where will they buy it, how many will they buy, at what price?
Secret #3: Thorough Management Information
Disclose detailed information about the management team, including their background and experience. This instills confidence and trust in potential investors.
Secret #4: Detailed Personal Information
While information about the management's professional background is necessary, personal details like addresses are not.
Secret #5: Financial Statements

Provide comprehensive financial statements. For a company combining traditional and decentralized financial systems, transparency in financial dealings is non-negotiable.

Secret #6: Internal Competitive Analysis

Detailed analysis of competitors or the competitive landscape is not a requirement.


ex with early BT diagram before TAD just ccompetiting with otehr transfer agents

Secret #7: Detail Potential Risks
Outline all potential risks associated with the investment. This includes market risks, regulatory risks, especially pertinent in blockchain and cryptocurrency markets, and any company-specific risks.
Secret #8: Market Size

Text or maybe ideally a good video on TAM and SAM (from GT?)

Secret #9: Top Core Values

EO?

An example of how you might share this info with investors can be found here. https://drive.blocktransfer.com/file/q13dn7989e9558e724cccaf2cff4837123334

Secret #10: Use of Money

Text

Text

Secret #11: External Support

Text

Secret #12: Business Validation

Customer Interviews/Discover vid from Standofrd thing startup school?

Secret #13: Internal Marketing Strategies

What you might want to disclose is just as important as what you might want to keep private. There is certainly material company inside knowledge which you shouldn't spell out for your competitotrs if you don't need to. The San Francisco founder from earlier mentioned a case study where a startup raised $66,000,000 from a single investor based soley on patents.

Along a similar line of thinking, specific marketing strategies and tactics arenât required in the PPM. 


competitors info ... etc

Secret #14: Product Mockups

Text

Secret #15: Pitch Deck Presentation

based on business plan


one to present with general picturs and such (see Secret #24) and one to share

Secret #16: Record a Video Pitch

Doesn't need to be perfect


Here's an example:

Secret #17: You May Need to Pivot
Learn More
Secret #18: Start With Why
Ideas are hardly new. What's new is solving an unsolved problem in an existing idea. For that, you first need to learn

I'm sorry to break your heartâsomebody out there has already come up with the same idea that you have. Somebody out there is already working on the same idea that you have. Don't over-index on the idea. Instead, find out what it is that they know that you don't. Because ideas are hardly new. What's new is solving an unsolved problem in an existing idea... You first need to learn... Your idea is not your startup. Your approach is your startup.

âAnkur Warikoo
Secret #19: Internal Future Business Endeavors

Plans for future business ventures, unless directly related to the use of proceeds, arenât necessary.

Secret #20: Get User Feedback to Uncover Trends
Secret #21: Company Roadmap

might be short-term, might be long-term

Secret #22: Learn Who Pays You

As the video above demonstraits, where you get actual money might not be so straightforward. Are you selling the idea to a grant program, getting cold hard cash from consumers, or some mix of the two? If you're selling to a business, who is the real buyer? I remember early on in Block Transfer; I asked a mentor how I might sell something to a company that nobody uses or cares about. That was before I spoke with four dozen public CFOs, as you might be able to tell by my naivety. In reality, he told me, someone's always using your product (this may be more apparent in your industry). Figure out who are the users and get on their side. After that, figure out who makes the actual purchase decision, if that's someone else in the company. Or just mail the product right to them in a simple consumer market. But don't skip this step! Just because a child uses the Lego set doesn't mean they're the one paying for it. Dig deep and uncover who really coughs up when it's time to send the payment, no matter who you think your users are. (Hint: ask them and pay attention to body language - many people get squeemish around money)

Secret #23: Offering Terms

Clearly detail the terms, including the type of securities offered, the price, and any restrictions on the transfer of the securities.

Secret #24: Internal Technical Documentation

fhdui hfudshuif uhdisf d  jdfisfjidosfjiods

How to Speak detials

Secret #25: Get Involved in a Launchpad
Secret #26: Internal Rudimentary Projections

talk about how like based on a hunch 


MNA ex 

Secret #27: Uncover Influential Support

Early idea validatipon, ex our story with Cormac Kinney leading to bitcoin post https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?topic=5387064.0

Success secret

Reach out to people you admire (or find them,) and see if they support you

Tie in to top gun/confidence

Secret #28: Give Big Investors What They Want

If a large investor reaches out to you


Example of requesting a cofounder from CREATEX


https://drive.blocktransfer.com/file/q13dn5c97bbea1e8c4a64923ab5186864118f

Secret #29: Sell to a Persona

Define your ideal clients

Secret #30: Market Discovery Insights

Story of client discovery / talking to market and wut learn

Secret #31: Legal Considerations
Disclose all legal aspects related to the offering. This includes any litigations, regulatory compliance, and adherence to securities laws.
Secret #32: Take a Class

Most people wouldn't bat an eye when it comes to going to class to be an accountant, engineer, or doctor. Why then should we pretend euntrepreunrship is just a natural talent? There's a plethora of online resources to grasp starting (and scaling) your own business. We always hear of (and I use) Audible as a great resource. Might I also recommend this course playlist from Harvard:

Audible for Free â
Secret #33: Look for Trends When Testing
Secret #34: Deeply Care About Your Market
Secret #35: Missionary vs. Mercenary

Having a passion is a gift. I think we all have passions, and you don't get to choose them. They pick you, but you have to be alert to them. You have to be looking for them. And when you find your passion, it's a fantastic gift for you because it gives you direction, it gives you purpose. You can have a job, or you can have a career, or you can have a calling. And the best thing is to have calling. And if you find your passion, you'll have that. And all your work won't feel like work to you.

JB

Secret #36: Third-Party Reports
If any third-party reports, such as audits or appraisals, have been used, their details must be disclosed.

He's not just a visionary with visions. He's an architect with blueprints and some notion of how to make things work. He thinks very carefully about design and structure and operations. And that's what turns a visionary into someone who actually accomplishes something.
Secret #37: Set Objectives and Key Results
Bonus Secret: Be Yourselves

You are now 'we'

item.title: 13 Ways How and Why to Set Compelling Startup Goals
item.dc:creator: John Wooten
item.content:encoded:
Prerequisite Reading: Personal Story. TLDR: This is part of our entrepreneurship / small business success series.

Embarking on the entrepreneurial journey is akin to setting sail on a vast, uncharted ocean. ð It's a path brimming with excitement, promise, and, admittedly, a fair share of challenges. Unlike the more straightforward course of finding a "regular" job, launching your own business is a testament to your commitment to a dream that extends far beyond the immediate horizon. ð This endeavor is not for the faint-hearted; it demands a blend of passion, â¤ï¸ resilience, and an unwavering belief in your vision. It's about embracing the long haul, recognizing that the seeds you plant today may take years to bear fruit. ð±
The essence of entrepreneurship transcends the mere act of creating a job for oneself; it's about building something enduring, something that can change lives, shape industries, and perhaps even leave a legacy. With this understanding, it becomes clear that starting a business is a long-term venture, one that requires not just a leap of faith but a well-thought-out plan that considers the distant future. ð®

I actually have read Think and Grow Rich by Napoleon Hill. Definitely a fantastic read!

I apply things that I've learned from that read everyday. In our business and in my personal life.

That was actually one of the best reading experiences in my life. Learning about what

some of the greatest, most successful entrepreneurs in his era had in common.

â Block Transfer Client

In the spirit of Hill's Think and Grow Rich, we recognize the monumental importance of setting forth with a clear end in mind. ð¯ This timeless piece, which laid the foundation for the personal development industry, teaches us the value of setting goals. But not just any goalsâlong-term goals that serve as the lighthouse guiding your venture through the fog of uncertainty. These are the aspirations that will not only inspire your team but also form the cornerstone of any successful startup pitch. Because, at its core, pitching your business is about telling a compelling story through your goals, weaving a narrative that captures the essence of your long-term vision. â¨

As we delve into the intricacies of when and if you should incorporate your venture, let's keep this fundamental truth at the forefront: entrepreneurship is a marathon, not a sprint. ðââï¸ð It's a journey that asks of you to look beyond the immediate, to plan with the end in sight, and to build a business that echoes your deepest aspirations and values. Welcome to the path less traveled, where the rewards, though not immediate, are truly immeasurable. ð

The Importance of Long-Term Goals

The art of setting long-term goals is both reflective and forward-looking. It requires an intimate understanding of the market, your business, and your personal aspirations. These goals should stretch the limits of your imagination yet remain within the realm of feasibility. They are the benchmarks of progress, the milestones that mark the journey of growth and achievement.

Vision: The Heartbeat of Your Startup â¤ï¸

A vision that lives only in your mind is like a sunken treasureâvaluable but inaccessible. Learn to communicate your vision in a way that is clear, compelling, and contagious. Whether it's through storytelling, visual aids, or demonstrations, your goal is to make others see what you see. ð Ask yourself what problem you're passionate about solving and why this mission matters to you. Your why is the foundation of your vision; it's what makes your startup not just a business, but a cause.

The essence of your entrepreneurial quest lies in the vision you hold for your venture. Long-term goals are the stars by which you navigate; they illuminate the path from where you are to where you wish to be. ð This vision is more than a destination; it's the heartbeat of your startup, pulsating through every aspect of your business, from product development to customer engagement.

Rallying Your Team Around the Vision ð¤

Your vision becomes truly powerful when it's shared. It should resonate with your team, aligning with their values and aspirations. Share your vision early and often, and make it a part of your company's culture. ð¡ When your team is fully aligned with the startup's vision, they are more motivated, engaged, and committed to the journey ahead.


A shared vision, articulated through well-defined long-term goals, is the glue that binds your team together. It transforms a collection of individuals into a unified force, each member driven by a common purpose. This unity is your startup's strength, enabling it to weather the storms and celebrate the victories as one cohesive unit. ð

The Bedrock of Your Pitch

In the world of startups, your vision is your most valuable asset in any early pitch. ð® It differentiates you from competitors and connects emotionally with your audience. When pitching, focus on how your long-term goals address a universal need or problem, and how your startup uniquely solves this. Your vision should paint a picture of a future made better by your company's success. ð¨


When it comes to sharing your vision with the world, whether it be investors, partners, or customers, the clarity and conviction of your long-term goals are your most persuasive tools. They weave the narrative of your business, a narrative that is compelling, aspirational, and grounded in a future you are bringing to life. This storytelling is not just persuasive; it's transformative, capable of turning listeners into believers, and believers into advocates. ð£ï¸

Subheading 3

Text

Sub-Sub-Heading 4

OKRs? talk about the 2 types! make gud

The Takeaway

Long-term goals are the essence of your entrepreneurial journey. They offer direction, inspire action, and unify your efforts. They are the foundation upon which your business's legacy will be built. With the right vision and determination, the possibilities are limitless. Let your long-term goals be the guiding light on your path to success, illuminating the way forward with clarity and purpose. ðâ¨


The journey towards your goals is as important as the goals themselves. It's a journey marked by continuous learning, adaptation, and resilience. It's about making choices that align with your vision, embracing opportunities for innovation, and persisting in the face of obstacles. Learn more about the equity management platform that helps you achieve you goals and schedule a free brief consultation.

This blog post is neither personalized for your circumstances nor legal advice.

item.title: Incorporating Your American Business: A Strategic Guide to If, When, and How
item.dc:creator: John Wooten
item.content:encoded:
Prerequisite Reading: Define Your Goals. TLDR: Know where you want to go before deciding to incorporate.

Embarking on the journey of incorporating your business venture may seem like a daunting task, filled with legal complexities and formal procedures. However, the truth is, at its core, incorporation is surprisingly straightforwardâessentially boiling down to a couple of pieces of paperwork and a modest State fee. ðð¼ This guide is designed to demystify the process, shining a light on the fact that you can take this significant step with confidence and ease.

Incorporation isn't just about crossing a legal threshold; it's a strategic move that lays the groundwork for your business's future success, offering a plethora of benefits from legal protection to tax advantages. By the end of this post, you'll see that transforming your business idea into a legally recognized entity is not just possible but entirely achievable with a few simple steps. ðâ¨

The time will never be just right. Start where you stand, and

work whatever tools you may have at your command...

Whatever your mind can conceive and believe, it can achieve.

â Napoleon Hill

Your incorporation paperwork comes with a suite of benefits and considerations, transforming your concept into a recognized entity in the business world. ð It's a step that solidifies your venture's foundation, preparing it for the challenges and triumphs ahead. 

Choosing the right business structure is a crucial decision that shapes not only how you operate but also impacts your financial and legal landscape. Each type of entity comes with its unique set of benefits, responsibilities, and considerations. Whether your sights are set on building a venture that will one day go public or nurturing a small business that aligns with your lifestyle, the decision to incorporate is pivotal, shaping the future of your endeavor. ð® 

Circumstances and Ambitions ð§ 

Before diving into the world of incorporation, it's crucial to recognize the stage of your entrepreneurial journey. Initially, you might want to keep your focus on understanding your audience and refining your value proposition. Incorporation comes into play when you're ready to solidify your business's structure, enhance your credibility, and embark on a formal path of growth. ð

Establish Business Goals With These 13 Secrets Before Incorporating

Sole Proprietorship: The Simple Start ð±

If you're in the phase of talking to potential clients, understanding the market, and exploring the problems your business aims to solve, a formal incorporation might not be immediately necessary. ð¤ At this juncture, your focus is on research and validationâengaging with your target audience to grasp their needs, pain points, and expectations. This exploratory phase is invaluable, as it shapes the foundation of your product or service, ensuring it's finely tuned to the market's demands.


A Sole Proprietorship stands as the epitome of simplicity in the business entity spectrum, eliminating the need for extensive paperwork or formalities to kickstart operations in most jurisdictions. This business structure is unincorporated, owned, and operated by a single individual, blurring the lines between the business and its owner. ð This lack of legal separation means the business is essentially an extension of the proprietor's personal financial landscape, and you'll pay self-employment taxes.

Since there's no distinction between the owner and the business, the income generated by the business is directly treated as the your individual income. Today, proprietors report business income or losses on Schedule C of Form 1040, which is then integrated into your personal tax return. ð This straightforward approach allows for an uncomplicated tax filing process, as it consolidates business and personal income into a single stream without any registration costs.
Read Chapter 8 Here If You're Not Familiar With Tax Filing Secrets

However, this simplicity comes with its considerations. The absence of legal separation means that your personal assets (e.g. home, car, and savings) are directly exposed to business liabilities. In the event of business debts or legal challenges, these personal assets could be at risk. Therefore, while the Sole Proprietorship offers ease and direct control, it demands a careful assessment of the potential vulnerabilities inherent in this entwined financial and legal structure.

Other Non-Corporation Structures ð 

While LLCs and other more personal business structures offer unique advantages, especially for early solopreneurs or small partnerships operating within professional services, they often fall short when it comes to scaling a business, leveraging online platforms, or attracting significant investment. ðð¡ I encountered unexpected challenges that underscored this viewpoint with my first blockchain startup, initially structured as an LLC and later taxed as an S-Corp.

Opting for an LLC seemed advantageous at the outset, offering flexibility and perceived simplicity. However, as we navigated the path towards growth and scalability, the limitations became increasingly apparent. Not only did we face higher state filing fees fueled by indecision around incorporating, but the LLC structure also introduced constraints that hindered our ability to effectively attract investment and scale online. ð¼ð

Timing is Key â

Once you've honed in on your market and your business idea has passed the crucial test of validation, stepping into the world of incorporation marks a pivotal moment in your entrepreneurial journey. ð This significant move is much more than a formal gesture; it's a declaration of your unwavering commitment and a signal that you're geared up to serve your clients on a robust, professional platform. But remember, timing is everything in this dance of business growth. ð°ï¸ð¼

When you decide to incorporate your business, it's crucial to consider the timing, especially in relation to annual fees. No matter when you incorporate during the year, you'll be responsible for paying the full annual fee. To avoid paying a full year's fee for just a short period of operation, consider incorporating early in the new year. This way, you can maximize your value for the annual fee and avoid the extra cost that comes with incorporating later in the year. ðâ¡ï¸ð¼

Establish Your Founding Team ð¤

Incorporation also marks a key opportunity to thoughtfully divide ownership stakes among those core team members, co-founders, early employees, and investors, setting the stage for your companyâs future. By issuing stock or equity options early on, you create a reward and incentive system that recognizes team contributions. This approach not only helps in acknowledging their early faith and hard work in your vision but also plays a crucial role in attracting future talent and investment. ðð By growing and sharing the pie, you can not only recognize and reward those who contribute to your company's early successes but also attract top talent and secure investment by offering a tangible piece of your startup's potential upside. ð±ð°

Selecting the right co-founders and early team members (and dividing equity) is a crucial decision, as these individuals will play a foundational role in your company's development and success. Your legal frameworks establish clear expectations and for how contributions to the company will be valued and rewarded, preventing misunderstandings and conflicts down the road. ð Whether itâs setting aside a portion of equity for future employees under a vesting schedule or negotiating option pool percentages with co-founders, the act of incorporating allows you to formalize these agreements in a way that supports your companyâs growth and aligns with your long-term vision. ð¤ This stage of the process requires a deliberate approach to building a cohesive team that shares your vision, work ethic, and commitment to navigating the complexities of startup growth.
Start Strong With 7 Secrets to Bootstrap a Productive Early Team

Drafting Your Articles of Incorporation ð

While you can create a specialized custom Articles of Incorporation, we find that most online providers stick with the standard minimal disclosure template avaliable for free from Delaware. Elabrate here, trasnsiton to importance of name, collaborative effort, potential market insight per 4 Hour Work Week

Delaware Legal Rules ð

The next pivotal step in your incorporation journey is naming your company. This isn't just about creativity or branding; it's about adhering to specific legal requirements and considerations. ðâ¨ Delaware's naming rules serve as a vital checkpoint in ensuring that your chosen company name not only reflects your brand identity but also complies with state regulations. These rules are designed to prevent confusion, protect trademarks, and clarify business activities through the name itself.

Delaware law requires the inclusion of specific suffixes in your business name, such as "Inc.," "Corporation," "Company," or abbreviations thereof. This clarifies your business as a registered corporation and is non-negotiable. ðð 
  • as âA,â âAnâ or âTheâ
  • The conjunction "And" or â&"
  • commas and periods
Corporate IdentifierStandard Abbreviation
AssociationAssoc.
CompanyCo.
CorporationCorp.
Club-
FoundationFdn.
Fund-
IncorporatedInc.
InstituteInst.
LimitedLtd.
SocietySoc.
Syndicate-
Union
-
Lastly, avoid restricted words like "bank," "university," or "insurance" which suggest your company operates in regulated industries, requiring specific licenses. Ensuring your name doesnât inadvertently step into these territories without the requisite permissions is key for a fast incorporation approval. ð«ð

Select an Available Name ð¬

Your company name must be distinct from existing entities registered in Delaware. You can start with the State's search tool to avoid legal disputes and confusion. A preliminary search through the Delaware Division of Corporations' website can help verify that your desired name is available. ðð¡

Start with a comprehensive search of the Delaware Division of Corporations' website to ensure your proposed name is not already in use by another entity within the state. The intent here is to make sure your name can't be confised for another company, which means minor differences could still create troubles down the road. This step is crucial for ensuring your name's uniqueness within Delaware's jurisdiction. ðð Once you have a "material precense...", you'll also need to register as a foreign entity in such state of operation. To avoid consumer confusion and potential liability, it's also best practice to search for similar names with your local Secretary of State.



Run your potential new name through a United States Patent and Trademark Office database search. Checking for similar or identical names in the USPTO's records can help avoid infringing on existing trademarks and patents, which is vital for preventing legal disputes and the need for a costly rebranding down the line.

In today's digital age, a comprehensive online search also includes domain names, social media handles, and DBA name registrations. ð Securing a domain efficiently ensures your online presence aligns with your corporate identity and facilitates brand consistency across platforms. â This thorough approach can identify potential issues you might overlook, saving you from future headaches and legal challenges. ð¼




Reflecting Your Business Purpose: While Delaware doesn't strictly require your company name to reflect your business purpose, choosing a name that gives insight into what your business does can be beneficial for brand clarity and marketing. ðð¥

As you embark on this naming process, remember that your company name is more than a label; it's the first point of engagement with your audience and the legal world. My own journey taught me the importance of a name that resonates on a market level while satisfying legal criteria.

searching on site, dba, and trademark [links]

When I started Mosey, it was originally incorporated as Mosey, Inc.

I ended up changing it to Mosey Works, Inc., because there was a name collision

in California, and I didnât want to waste time filing DBAs everywhere we operated.

This spares me a few days of work per year and thousands of dollars in additional legal bills,

not to mention the tediousness of keeping track of the right names to use and remembering to renew.

â Alex Kehayias, Founder/CEO

However, once you feel confident and prepared to dive into the business world with full force, the next significant step is choosing the right company structure, such as an S-Corp or a C-Corp. Opting for an S-Corp, through Form 2553 after incorporation, might be the ideal path if you're envisioning a small, closely-held enterprise. This route offers the perks of professional recognition, separate financial tracking, and potential tax benefits. ðâ¨

S-Corporation: The Middle Ground ð

Incorporating too early, especially when you're still gauging interest and gathering feedback, could send a mixed message to potential clients. It might appear as though you're rushing to sell something before fully understanding what the market truly needs. ðââï¸ð¼ This perception could deter the open and honest feedback that's crucial at this stage. Your goal is to build relationships and trust, positioning yourself as a solution provider who genuinely wants to address the challenges faced by your potential customers, not just someone eager to make a quick sale. ð¸

That said, once you're ready to wholeheartedly go into business, you'll need to pick between an S-Corp or a C-Corp. The S-Corp is a special election you can make once you incoporate using form 2553. If you're planning a closely-held small business, then this could be your ticket to professionalism, segregated accounting, and tax savings. Get to take payroll which gets taxed nromally but also distributions which only face income tax. Also have to file a sperate tax accounting return for the buesinss. 
This 3-Person Team Defeated a $100M+ Incumbent Without Investors

C-Corporation: The Corporate Giant ð¢

However, the path of incorporation varies, ranging from the robust C-Corp structureâdesigned to attract investors and scale quicklyâto the more streamlined Sole Proprietorships and S-Corps, which offer simplicity and tax benefits tailored to smaller businesses who want to grow organically. ð 
There's a saying at Google that you can't test software at scale until it's at scale. We tend to agree with the sentimants that you might not really know what works best until you give it a shot. That's why, if you're starting out small, working solo on your own budding venture, to incorporate or not might not be as straightforward as you think. ð¤

Incorporation can also navigate your startup towards more favorable tax waters. Depending on your jurisdiction and the structure you choose, you may unlock tax benefits and incentives previously out of reach. These advantages can significantly impact your financial planning, allowing for more efficient allocation of resources towards growth and innovation. ð¡ But all that only matters if you make signficianty reveneus. Depending on 







Do these benefits apply to your venture? For many, business maturity, maximizing profits, and external fundraising aren't top priorities. Starting as a sole proprietorship offers a straightforward path, especially for small or lifestyle businesses. This simplicity can be a significant advantage when the complexities of incorporation seem like towering mountains on your entrepreneurial map.

At the heart of this decision is the essence of your journey. Are you experimenting with a concept, testing the waters to see if your idea can take flight? Or are you ready to dive deep into the realms of the business world, eager to claim your stake and grow your venture? The path of incorporation is paved with formalities, paperwork, and legal intricacies, a voyage that can be daunting for lone founders. ðºï¸


But let's not forget, incorporation isn't merely a legal checkpoint; it's a milestone that signifies your commitment to nurturing your idea into a thriving business. It heralds the beginning of a new chapter, where your venture steps out of the shadows of being a mere idea into the light of a recognized entity. This transformation brings with it the promise of new opportunities, the potential for investment, and the dream of building a legacy.



As you ponder the decision to incorporate, remember, the timing is key. There's a season for everything, and just as a seed needs time to germinate before it can bloom, your startup may need to marinate in the incubator of your passion and hard work before it's ready to flourish as a corporation. Whether you choose to incorporate now or later, the most important thing is to remain true to your vision, adaptable in your approach, and steadfast in your journey towards success.


Legal Identity: A Shield of Protection ð¡ï¸

move these up, introduce filing https://corp.delaware.gov/fee/

Incorporating your startup bestows it with a legal identity separate from your own. This separation is akin to crafting a sturdy shield, protecting your personal assets from business liabilities. Whether facing financial challenges or legal disputes, incorporation ensures that your personal realm remains safeguarded, allowing you to take calculated risks with confidence.

Credibility and Trust: The Key to New Horizons ðï¸

Having "Inc." or "LLC" in your business name isn't just a matter of prestige; it's a beacon of trust and professionalism. ð¼ This level of credibility can open doors to new opportunities, attracting investors, partners, and customers who are more inclined to do business with a company that's officially recognized. It's like receiving a seal of approval that amplifies your startup's reputation in the market.

Fundraising and Growth: Fueling Your Ambitions ð

For startups looking to the future, fundraising is often a critical component of scaling operations. Incorporation makes your venture more attractive to potential investors, as it allows for the issuance of shares and clearly defines the structure of ownership. This clarity and formalization can be the fuel your startup needs to soar to new heights, transforming ambitious goals into tangible achievements.

Incorporating your startup is a step towards building something enduringâa legacy that outlives the founders. It's about laying the foundation stones of your empire, setting the stage for future generations to inherit and build upon. ð° This permanence ensures that your vision and values are preserved, enabling your business to continue making an impact well into the future.

Subheading 3


As the Delaware division filer points out, Offer guidance on the right timing for incorporation, considering factors such as business maturity, revenue generation, and the need for external funding. Lowest costs simply doing it under your own name when the stakes are low.

But if you have grander visions, Explain how choosing the right type of incorporation (e.g., LLC, S-Corp, C-Corp) can support your long-term goals and growth strategy. LLC is really just a proxy to let you use sole-props, partnerships, corporations, etc. But in most cases when you're ready for formal organization you'll go with incorpoaiton anyway. Lower state filing fees.


a well-structured company can attract more investors.
incorporating your venture or getting external venture validation allows you to tell a compelling story to potential investors/partners.
craft a narrative that highlights your long-term vision, the strategic role of incorporation, and the potential impact on your industry.

Sub-Sub-Heading 4

If your business physically operates, hires employees, or has a significant physical presence in states outside of Delaware, you might need to register as a "foreign" entity in those states. This is what's often referred to as "foreign qualification." It means you're letting other states know you're doing business there, which is important for compliance and tax reasons.


each state has its own rules about what constitutes "doing business," and these can include factors like having a physical office, employing people, or even holding inventory there. It's crucial to consult with a legal or tax professional to navigate this landscape accurately and ensure you're fully compliant. ð§­

https://content.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2053895,00.html

Get an EIN

https://www.irs.gov/businesses/small-businesses-self-employed/apply-for-an-employer-identification-number-ein-online

Bylaws, very nuanced and about how you specifically want your company run - Bylaws even set policies like running a board meeting over video, rather than strictly IRL.

Plenty of templates and not something you need at the initial inciropiration, but establuishess your corporate veil seperating the company from founding shareholdlers.

Will offer 3 things to recognize as you draft potentially with others:

- Do not add blanket stock transfer restrictions or rights of first refusal. If you want to buy back stock, you can do so in the secondary market. It's bad practice to force shareholders, often dedicated early employees, to ask for permission every time they want to transfer stock. Save yourself the administrative headaches and enable your shares to trade with whoever will pay the most for them, boosting yours.

- Go with uncertificated stock, in ellectronic book-entry form. And, if you happen to use a blockchain transfer agent, we reccomend specifying that shares are divisible up to seven decimal places.

- Place some consideration into an alternate fiscal year if your business is seasonal, has established buying cycles not ending in December, etc.

Incorporating your business requires ongoingaction to keep up to par, setting up your accounting experts and managing books:

item.title: How to Mesmerize Users: Ram's 13 Principles for Jaw-Droppingly Front Ends
item.dc:creator: John Wooten
item.content:encoded:
Img 1600 x 667px, fit as "Large"

Prerequisite Reading: Thing. TLDR: relevant info.

Introduction Hook.

Heading 2

Text

Subheading 3

from As Little Design As Possible

One has to understand the wishes and expectations of the user. One must know the limitations of the technology and the production. One has to understand the market and understand what is best left alone and what would be plain fraud.

â Dieter Rams

Sub-Sub-Heading 4

1. The first question is not if one should be designing something but how. 2. Is the product that we are designing really necessary? Are there not already other, similar, tried and tested appliances that people have got used to and are good and functional? Is innovation in this instance really necessary? 3. Will it really enrich peopleâs lives or does it just appeal to their covetousness, possessiveness or ideas of status? Or does it wake desire because it is offering something new? 4. Is it conceived for the short- or long-term, does it just help increase the speed of the cycle of throwaway goods or does it help slow it down?

5. Can it be simply repaired or does it rely on an expensive customer services facility? Can it in fact be repaired at all or is the whole appliance rendered redundant when just one part of it breaks? 6. Does it exhibit fashionable and therefore aesthetically short-lived design elements? 7. Does it help people or incapacitate them? Does it make them more free or more dependent? 8. Is it so accomplished and perfect that it perhaps incapacitates or humiliates you? 9. Which previous human activity does it replace and can that really be called progress? 10. What possibilities for change, what scope does the product offer people? 11. Can the product be used in other, perhaps playful, ways? 12. Does the product really offer convenience or does it encourage passivity? 13. What does the expected improvement look like in a broader context? 14. Does it make an action or activity on the whole more complicated or simpler; is it easy to operate or do you have to learn how to use it? 15. Does it arouse curiosity and the imagination? Does it encourage desire to use it, understand it and even to change it?

Recently, my girlfriend asked me how short a girl could cut her hair before she wasn't sexy. In another exchange, a prominant venture capitalism said explaining raising money was akin to talking about sex. In this post, we'll explore the implkication of both of these viewpoints, where we disagree, and how it affects what you can invest in.

Tak about origins of xlm and tie into fairly convincing argument of disinterested founders at beginning of blockchain industry and kinda overall nonprofit social advancements as foundation of web3. 6 security audits on protocol 20 upgrade per developer. Meeting with multiple s d employees comma core developers comma and tomayor on 26 Jan 2024 at 1pm) ___ emphasis Tomer Comments and community action posts

Subheading 3

Bitcoin is a peer-to-peer system. Individual investors in the U.S. who want to invest in the product may already do so, either by mining it themselves or by setting up a wallet and buying it from someone else, each of which they are able to do from the comfort of their living room. That is the whole point of creating a new, censorship-resistant digital currency. So why is so much energy being expended on linking it to the existing financial system? I fear that our actions today are not providing investors access to new investments, but instead providing the investments themselves access to new investors in order to prop up their price. While this is in the interests of the sponsors of the ETPs, as well as the law firms and service providers who will get paid by them, my duty is to consider investors, markets, and the public, whose overall interests I do not believe are in fact well-served today.


original emphasis


Commissioner Caroline A. Crenshaw

Not to mention Bastiatâs unseen, the great innovations which do not exist

because their brilliant creators were too scared of prosecution.

I bet there are thousands of innovators reading these sentences with tears in their eyes,

because they didnât have $100k to spend on preliminary legal review.

Occamâs Razor: the reason the SEC hasnât produced such a list is because

itâs not clear at all which tokens are classifiable and enforceable as securities.

Itâs not clear to the SEC.

Itâs not clear to industry participants.

Itâs not clear to lawyers.

And itâs not clear to the public who buy and sell these things. 





had Ethereum been explicitly classified as a security upon its initial crowdsale,

the SEC wouldâve smothered in its crib one of the greatest world-changing inventions

in human history.

Front-ends designed and built by hobbyists and enthusiasts would disappear,

and this gets more frightening when one realizes that

most early Bitcoin companies were simply projects set up by hobbyists and enthusiasts.



And from the userâs perspective, sure, the technical could still legally engage directly with a smart contract via command prompt (or would command prompt software be considered an interface?), but for 99% of people, defi would become tradfi. 

[tie into exact tornadoCash case]

item.content:encoded:

Prerequisite Reading: Thing. TLDR: relevant info.

Introduction Hook.

Heading 2

Absolutely, let's outline a blog post that addresses the growing concerns about platforms that combine investor account management (akin to transfer agents) with secondary trading through a private alternative trading system (ATS). This outline will avoid mentioning any specific companies, focusing instead on the general issues and trends in the industry.



---



**Title:** Navigating the Complexities of Modern Equity Management Platforms



**Introduction:**

- Briefly introduce the emergence of modern equity management platforms that combine investor account management with secondary trading.

- Mention the growing popularity of these platforms among startups and private companies.

- Highlight the intent of the blog post: to discuss the challenges and potential pitfalls of such platforms.



**Section 1: The Allure of Integrated Equity Management Platforms**

- Explain the convenience and efficiency of having investor account management and secondary trading in one platform.

- Discuss the benefits for companies and investors, such as streamlined processes, centralized data, and ease of access to private markets.



**Section 2: Transparency and Trust Issues**

- Address the concern of transparency in pricing and fees in secondary markets.

- Discuss how the lack of clear pricing mechanisms can lead to distrust among platform users.

- Reference industry trends showing a demand for more transparent pricing structures.



**Section 3: Customer Service Challenges**

- Elaborate on common customer service issues faced by users of these platforms.

- Include general examples such as delayed responses, unresolved queries, and technical glitches.

- Emphasize the importance of robust customer support in financial services.



**Section 4: Conflicts of Interest and Ethical Concerns**

- Discuss potential conflicts of interest when a platform manages investor accounts and also facilitates trades.

- Explore the ethical implications of having access to sensitive company and investor information.

- Mention general industry concerns about the use of proprietary data in secondary market transactions.



**Section 5: Navigating Secondary Market Access**

- Examine the limitations and barriers to accessing secondary markets on such platforms.

- Discuss how these limitations can impact liquidity and investment opportunities for smaller investors.

- Mention general industry calls for more inclusive and accessible secondary market mechanisms.



**Conclusion:**

- Summarize the key points discussed in the blog.

- Highlight the need for balanced regulation and enhanced industry standards to address these issues.

- Encourage investors and companies to conduct thorough due diligence when selecting a platform.



**Call to Action:**

- Invite readers to share their experiences and thoughts on the topic.

- Provide links to related resources or forums for further discussion.



---

item.title: Do Stockbrokers Exist in Web 3? We Think Yes
item.dc:creator: John Wooten
item.content:encoded:
Capstone Team Award --- Img 1600 x 667px, fit as "Large"

Prerequisite Reading: TAD3 Introduction. TLDR: We use distributed ledger technology to fix Wall Street's bugs.

Two years ago Block Transfer went through the senior design course at Georgia Tech. [ELABORATE HERE CREATEX AND FOR ECE ETC] During the class, I pitched the Syndicate three times to the ~200 person class, its professors, and 25â35 mentors. We only had 7 minutes per pitch, so I filtered down our admittedly complex explanation of how we fix Wall Street. (Thankfully, we now have WhyDRS.org)

After each pitch, we fielded quested for just 5 minutes. In an effort to hear as many viewpoints as possible, I routinely cut students off, gave overtly frank answers, and hastily moved on to the next question. Needless to say, I wasn't very popular. In fact, we consistantly received the worst student rankings out of all the teams. But the Design Expo judges thought otherwise (award pitcured above).

A Pointed Question

What happens to brokers in your system?

â Anonymous Student

At the time, I retorted: "They go bankrupt."

Past Reasoning

TAD3 came from observing our present inefficient, problematic, and centralized capital market. It all started when I realized that an average stock trade goes through 11 middlemen. At the time, I thought that these banks, brokers, and custodians had to be the problem.

Thoughts Since

I've grown over the past years building Block Transfer from nothing, speaking with countless successful American businesses, and supporting our first small issuer from South Carolina. Before this startup, the closest thing I had to a "real job" was managing a Subway. That was 7 years ago now.


Over time, I've come to greatly appreciate capitalism's unique ability to efficiently organize society without centralization. Incredibly, the lure of prosperity, when combined with information accessability, defined my life goal.

A Deeper Flaw

Some middlemen in our current stock trading system charge hidden fees, pay exorbitant salaries, and practice unfair business. For instance, academics have shown repeatedly that HFT co-location increases everyday volatility, real spreads, and settlement failures. But stock exchanges keep selling fiber lines to server farms next door for billions, enabled by misinformation, blatant fraud, and inadequate education.


The problem is for profit structure

jdfsio fds

fdks oifds


incentive to sell to best csotmiers etc


following rules for corporation

Manifestation Into a Secret Monopoly

Introduce the DTCC

Is capital infrastructure a marketable good or a public service?

item.title: Regulation D - How Startups Raise Money Compliantly with Rule 506
item.dc:creator: John Wooten
item.content:encoded:
In today's startup financing landscape, Rule 506 offerings under Regulation D emerge as not just a method, but arguably the best and most efficient route for early-stage fundraising. ð This regulatory framework serves as a cornerstone, offering a structured and accessible path for startups seeking to fuel their growth and aspirations. It represents a crucial gateway to success, providing a solid foundation for entrepreneurs to launch and scale their ventures. ðð¼

In the vibrant world of startups, Rule 506 is much more than a regulation; it's a journey, a story of ambition and savvy. It's the go-to phrase for "private placement" and stands as a testament to the spirit of modern early-stage capitalism. ðð¼


The SEC guidance streamlines, clarifies, and enhances what was once a somewhat ambiguous part of the original U.S. Securities Act, specifically Section 4(a)(2). ð This rule underwent modernization under President Obama, becoming a significant element of the JOBS Act. Rooted in principles that predate modern market regulations, Rule 506 stands as a pivotal tool for early business funding. ð It embodies the same principles that iconic figures like the Wright brothers, EstÃ©e Lauder, and Thomas Edison relied upon to launch their groundbreaking ventures.

The Startup Founder Standard âï¸

Our own tale with Rule 506 began with the birth of our family fund. Picture this: a team brimming with ideas, eager to grow our assets and client base. Our counsel suggested Rule 506 as the key. ð But, driven by a blend of curiosity and a thirst for knowledge, we chose a path less traveled. ð¤ï¸

For four years, we immersed ourselves in the complexities of securities laws. ð It was a journey filled with late nights, countless coffees, and moments of revelation. â Each clause, each subsection, became a part of our story, our identity. And then, in a twist fit for a movie, after our most successful year, we returned all investor funds. It was our way of staying true to our core values and commitment to integrity. ð«

Rule 506 has two main chapters: Subsection B, where you connect with investors you know, keeping the essence of the deal close and personal. It's like inviting trusted friends to a secret garden. ð¿ð¤ And then there's Subsection C, akin to casting a net into the vast ocean of accredited investors, full of potential and promise. ðð¢

Subsection B

Rule 506(b) stands as the more traditional route in the world of private placements, focusing on investors within your existing network. This subsection is about leveraging connections with people you already know and trust. ð¥

In the realm of Rule 506(b), your investors aren't just names on a spreadsheet; they're friends, early users, industry advisors - people you've met and interacted with outside of just pitching your company. ð¤ It's about nurturing relationships that have grown organically over time, rather than seeking new ones solely for investment purposes.

This approach isn't just a preference; it's where the vast majority of Regulation D offering money comes from. A significant 94% of Reg. D funds are raised through this method, according to an SEC study. ðð° The reason for this overwhelming preference for 506(b) over 506(c) is clear: the power of existing relationships and the trust that comes with them is invaluable. ð

Subsection C

Rule 506(c) presents a different landscape in private placements: it's all about reaching investors you don't yet know. This option can appeal to businesses that may have limited access to traditional funding sources or a small circle of affluent contacts. ðð¡ The offering type opens a path for those who dare to venture beyond their immediate circles, promising access to a wider pool of investors. ð Itâs about creatively and strategically making new connections in the vast ocean of potential backers, ð especially before you have a business generating cash.

Case Study

Consider the story of our first client, a minority-owned small business struggling to secure funding from banks, VCs, and credit providers due to limited financial resources. Their solution? They purchased an email list of 1,000 accredited investors and sent out their pitch deck, a strategy made possible under Rule 506(c). ð§ð

Challenges

However, reaching out to unfamiliar investors isn't without its hurdles:
    • Getting Noticed: In a digital age where cold emails and social media ads are the norms, standing out is tough. These methods can be costly and are often perceived as untrustworthy by professionals. Making a positive first impression this way can be challenging. ð»ð That's why we generally see more fundraising success through local startup networking events. ð
    • Building Trust: Once you have their attention, the next challenge is convincing these investors of your credibility and the potential of your team. ð¼ It's about selling not just your business, but also yourselves as trustworthy and capable leaders. ð¤ Robust LinkedIn profiles can be a game-changer here, helping to quickly establish credibility and professionalism. ð

Contrast this with investors in your existing network, who likely already have a favorable view of you and your work ethic. This familiarity can significantly lower the barrier to securing investment. ð¸

The Takeaway

A venture investor recently told us of a startup they funded where the founders ended up shelling out about 7% of the total investment ($30,000 to be precise) in legal fees. $30,000 for what really costs under $500 in State filing fees. We think that kind of moneyâwasted cash for standardized filingsâshould really go towards your mission, innovations, and people.


That's why picking the right offering structure matters so much when you fund your business with equity. 


Your offering type dictates the specific group to whom the company can sell stock. It does not control secondary transactions between investors after a statutory period of time. If you want your investors to have the most seamless shareholder experience available (including private trades), consider Block Transfer. As the Web3 Transfer Agent Depository, we can offer your company private placement services and so much more. Schedule a free brief consultation here.

Reference Materials

SEC Small Business Advocacy Report

item.title: More Eyes on Your Compnay? Increasing Startup Valuations
item.dc:creator: John Wooten
item.content:encoded:
Img 1600 x 667px, fit as "Large"

Prerequisite Reading: Thing. TLDR: relevant info.

"Transparency is good. Itâs that simple. Except in matters of national security, I canât think of another situation where obfuscation is a good idea."
â Fred Wilson
https://avc.com/2004/05/transparency-2/

When my old team and I invested in public markets, we generally looked at about 100 stocks for every investment we made. We've found similar trends among other asset managers. For us, that means analyzing often hundreds of pages of public company information before even looking at a stock price chart. Before any trading, the big question was always "is this a good firm?"







I asked that San Francisco founder how they'd feel about making public online their basic business information and financial statements. They told us that they'd be more comfortable posting limited information on Crunchbase. More specifically, he told us they used the allure of financial details, business specifics, and operational practices as a sort of bait for qualified investors. Certainly there exists some merit to the idea. But our fundamental question to him was simple:

Heading 2

Text

Subheading 3

Text

Would more eyes on your company increase its potential valuation?

Sub-Sub-Heading 4

https://www.sec.gov/files/2022-oasb-annual-report.pdf


Thing is, per that same SEC study, the distance between a lead angel investor and their target company averages only 37 miles. ð¤¯ If you can only fundraise in your own backyard, then naturally only a limited number of investors can even consider your company. And with only a small number of perspectices, you could really be passing up the chance for an investor that truly believes in your product, service, or mission. Anectdotally, these passionate early investors that "click" with founders are the most helpful down the road.

How do we increase your offering's diversity and, perhaps most importantly for increasing business value, reach? Could the answer lie in a more public disclosure of your company vision? I'll lay out some rules of thumb for this later in the post, but I want to tell you one more story before we dive into the schemantics of having a great private placement. Feel free to skip ahead if you just want the facts.




Only few investors get access and therefore to get to price the company, as opposed to the hundreds of thousands of investors who might have priced the company differently if they had access in a more open market


The Takeaway

What follows are some best practices we've picked up over the years through our own efforts and those of small-business clients. They are based around our public disclosure platform. Issuers.info was one of the first things we built at Block Transfer because transaprent company disclosuresâone of our core valuesâare not very well disseminated today. In fact, your normal stockbroker has details very similar to those hosted on our platform. But that information isn't generally publically accessable, leading many investors to turn to outside data sources like Yahoo Finance or Bloomberg. We appreciate the former, but the data it leverages often comes from select media outlets rather than the actual underlying company. And you shouldn't need to pay $25,000 a month to get that data from the latter. Of course, if you're like most startups, these two aren't even relevant.

item.title: First Blockchain Startup: 9 Founder Mistakes I Learned the Hard Way
item.dc:creator: John Wooten
item.content:encoded:
Prerequisite Reading: Family Entrepreneurship. TLDR: I'm the fourth in a heritage of American entrepreneurs.

This post lays out some more of my background and business perspective to start our series on building your own successful venture. ð Just over 7 years ago, I started researching financial markets after working a (great) minimum-wage job because I was tired of working open to close alone. Since then, I quit my one and only corporate gig to trade stocks full-time. I was hooked after making more in two weeks (on paper) than the entire year prior. It lit a spark inside that lead me to sleep for two hours a day for over half a year at Georgia Tech, just to best trade currency futures.


Along the way, I uncovered the revolutionary potential of blockchain technology through the world of cryptocurrency investments. After I lost $100,000 I'd generated solely from investment returns, I knew there had to be something special about these new distributed ledgers. That's when I founded my first blockchain startup, MonerAds, foraying itno the statup world.

Collaboration from Day One

From sales and marketing to technical development skills, MonerAds was my "real world" MBA in how to (not) launch a compnay. We never spoke to a single end-consumer (not one!) from ograization inception to eventual retirement. With no mentors to guide me then, I turned to free online resources for advice. Although little of what was avaliable back then helped us succeed, this appraoch did deeply embed in me an appreciation for distributed free quality education. That's why I'm writing our latest blog series for new business founders.

Constant Personal Help

Early on, I remember asking my high-school math teacher to explain some wierd aspect of the obscure Mimblewimble cryptographic protocol (yes, I handed him the actual whitepaper). Since then, I've stumped a number of tutors asking about wierd cryptography. Although many of these advisors didn't exactly understand our business, their perspectives were instrumental in crafting our service descriptions and theoretical value proposition.

On that note, after a 3-page formal incporation, I teamed up with a talented frontend developer I'd knwon since middle school. Importantly, this was a collaboration of convenience---specifically mine. I mocked up some template employement contracts and we agreed to split future revenues. Just like that our new tech startup was born.

Product-Focused Vision

Our idea was to help online newspapers losing money because of ad blockers. While some major sites at the time would display a popup asking you to disable your ad blocker, none of them had a true way to monetize these readers outside of subscriptions. We saw an opportunity as avid adblock users ourselves in an age before adblock detectors and the hard paywalls seen today. We racked our brains together to come up with a way that any reader could contribute to the site, even if they got annoyed by obtrusive ads.


An innovative new cypto at the time called Monero was our answer. Due to cool math things, Monero is/was (haven't been following recent developments) super efficient to "mine" on standard computers, laptoips, or phones. That means you can create a relatively meaninful amount of the cryptocurrency by just running its blockchain algorithms on your computer.


Over a couple years after school, we basically built a system where you could run a Monero miner directly in your browser (it was a very crude implementation looking back). Then our idea was that you could have this popup on the articles:

Developing the Vision

Long story short, I was responsible for marketing the tech, and I had quite a ways to go with my sales and social skills. I actually walked into AMD's downtown Charlotte headquarters and asked to speak to Lisa Su. And needless to say our lengthy sales letters to local papers didn't yield any clients.

Secret #4: Outsource Early and Often

If you read that last sales letter then you'd notice how much I talked about myself rather than actual product benefits, client needs, etc. But aside from poor form, you'd also see a whole section talking about how I spent months diving into IRS publications, corporate tax codes, and comprehensive accounting practices. This information certainly helped me down the road founding a transfer agent, but it was a rediculous use of resources at the time. As a broke high school student, I didn't think I could hire an accountant or talk to any professionals. That was a naive and scarse viewpoint that I think ultimately led the company to statis, whereby I wouldn't hire anybody to do important development work that needed more R&D efforts. Rather, I took the DIY approach and tried to figure everythng out myself---resulting in tremendous knowledge very useful now; but zero revenue, publisher users, or media attention.

Read the episode transcript

More on One Funnel Away

We never ended up raising funds, and the business ultimately ended up dying out. But, as I tell the story recently as an ecample, some investors still think the idea has merit. Now, this isn't what I'm really passionate about, so don't expect to see MonerAds poping into your life anytime soon. Not even sure it would work anymore. But the questino remains: we only spoke to one VC guy about our idea, and all the public media we posted about the company only garnered a few dozen observations. Might the business have went somewhere with a more broad basis of investors considering its mission?

Sub-Sub-Heading 4

Text

continueed pitching while trying to bootstrap, but received little interest

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vxRcWod3gI8&list=PLWUFvhKuc_5tVzjb1xXSnpVx0E42K3nQD&index=5

Text

Ending bootstrapp / trying to raise

Kinda thought it was silly that the opinion of a few people determined whether or not the venture got funded

response to vc - https://drive.blocktransfer.com/external/bcbb105eba713ecd58d6603add59cfca75cb4fcb89aba1aba6079540d8b3e4c0

item.title: Private Placement Contracts: Traditional Startup Fundraising
item.dc:creator: John Wooten
item.content:encoded:
If you're a private company raising money, you might have heard about "private placement memorandums." ð¸ These documents exist because of the plethora of securities laws governing how investors give you money. ð When it's time to raise your investment round, adhering to these rules ensures smooth growth for everyone. âµ

Just last year, the SEC reported $2,869,000,000,000 raised through domestic private offerings. ð Including foreign investors, the sum raises to 40% of all the funds raised in America. ð½ You can capture a share of this massive capital influx by issuing a standard "SAFE," convertible note, or "KISS" agreement. Compared to just selling shares at market prices, these early placement agreements let you raise cash without a company value. ð Negotiation between founders and investors depends on your circumstances, the market, and business history. ð

Closing a Placement

In the early days of your business, closing a financing round like a private placement comes down to your ability to imagine, convey, and deliver on a promising venture vision. Once you master these core business skills, it just comes down to the right audience. ð¼ An executive of our client said one surefire approach to convince investors:

"Do something that you love, because you'll put in the work behind it."

â Angel Laylor

We are currently streamlining the offering process through smart contracts that put these agreements on Soroban, so that you can raise from any verified users of Stellar. This is just one example of continuing to work steadfastly while racking up momentum, clientele, and experience. When you can just stick with your work, stuff will happen:

Relevant insights, albeit inspired by TVDH.

Pitching your startup can be one of the best ways to quickly understand your value proposition to investors and the market you'll serve. ð£ï¸ As Min-Liang Tan popularized, this can well start off with building something both "for and by" your community. Once you're off to the races building, it's a very short leap to selling inaugural users.
